Key Match Events: The Dodgers were handed a three-run deficit twice in the first two games of the NLDS.
Freddie Freeman left the game due to an ankle injury, forcing the Dodgers to adjust their lineup.
Max Muncy hit a solo home run in the ninth inning, cutting the deficit to eight.
Pre-Game Insights: The Dodgers entered the game needing to prove their ability to slug through the playoffs after a tough Game 2 performance.
Manager Dave Roberts emphasized the importance of scoring first and improving their starting pitching performance.
Post-Match Reflections: Max Muncy expressed frustration with the team's performance but remained confident in their ability to bounce back.
Manager Dave Roberts acknowledged the challenge of the lineup's performance and the impact of Freddie Freeman's injury.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The game was marred by a 10-minute delay after a baseball was thrown onto the field and trash was thrown at Fernando Tatis Jr.
The Dodgers' performance was described as 'not boxing' by Miguel Rojas, highlighting the physical and mental challenges of the game.
Others: The Dodgers' lineup, including former MVPs, struggled to produce hits, particularly Mookie Betts, who was hitless in his past 22 at-bats.
